solution_line_template: She puts ${contribution_per_paycheck} into her 401k from every paycheck and she gets {paychecks_per_year} paychecks so that's {contribution_per_paycheck}*{paychecks_per_year} = $<<{contribution_per_paycheck}*{paychecks_per_year}={annual_personal_contribution}>>{annual_personal_contribution}

Her company matches her ${contribution_per_paycheck} by 6% so they contribute {contribution_per_paycheck}*{match_rate_decimal} = $<<{contribution_per_paycheck}*{match_rate_decimal}={company_contribution_per_paycheck}>>{company_contribution_per_paycheck} every paycheck

Over a year, the company contributes ${company_contribution_per_paycheck} to her 401k with every paycheck so they contribute {company_contribution_per_paycheck}*{paychecks_per_year} = $<<{company_contribution_per_paycheck}*{paychecks_per_year}={annual_company_contribution}>>{annual_company_contribution}

Holly puts ${annual_personal_contribution} into her 401k annually and her company contributes ${annual_company_contribution} annually so she has {annual_personal_contribution}+{annual_company_contribution} = $<<{annual_personal_contribution}+{annual_company_contribution}={total_annual_contribution}>>{total_annual_contribution} in her 401k
